sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Now is the winter of our discontent
Made glorious summer by this sun of York;
And all the clouds that lour'd upon our house
In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths;
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments;
Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,
Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
Grim-visaged war hath smooth'd his wrinkled front;
And now, instead of mounting barded steeds
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,
He capers nimbly in a lady's chamber
To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass;
I, that am rudely stamp'd, and want love's majesty
To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
I, that am curtail'd of this fair proportion,
Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time
Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,
And that so lamely and unfashionable
That dogs bark at me as I halt by them;
Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to spy my shadow in the sun
And descant on mine own deformity:
And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover,
To entertain these fair well-spoken days,
I am determined to prove a villain
And hate the idle pleasures of these days.
Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,
By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,
To set my brother Clarence and the king
In deadly hate the one against the other:
And if King Edward be as true and just
As I am subtle, false and treacherous,
This day should Clarence closely be mew'd up,
About a prophecy, which says that 'G'
Of Edward's heirs the murderer shall be.
Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here
Clarence comes.

Brother, good day; what means this armed guard
That waits upon your grace?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
His majesty
Tendering my person's safety, hath appointed
This conduct to convey me to the Tower.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Upon what cause?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: Because my name is George.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours;
He should, for that, commit your godfathers:
O, belike his majesty hath some intent
That you shall be new-christen'd in the Tower.
But what's the matter, Clarence? may I know?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Yea, Richard, when I know; for I protest
As yet I do not: but, as I can learn,
He hearkens after prophecies and dreams;
And from the cross-row plucks the letter G.
And says a wizard told him that by G
His issue disinherited should be;
And, for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in his thought that I am he.
These, as I learn, and such like toys as these
Have moved his highness to commit me now.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Why, this it is, when men are ruled by women:
'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower:
My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, 'tis she
That tempers him to this extremity.
Was it not she and that good man of worship,
Anthony Woodville, her brother there,
That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,
From whence this present day he is deliver'd?
We are not safe, Clarence; we are not safe.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
By heaven, I think there's no man is secure
But the queen's kindred and night-walking heralds
That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.
Heard ye not what an humble suppliant
Lord hastings was to her for his delivery?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Humbly complaining to her deity
Got my lord chamberlain his liberty.
I'll tell you what; I think it is our way,
If we will keep in favour with the king,
To be her men and wear her livery:
The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,
Since that our brother dubb'd them gentlewomen.
Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
I beseech your graces both to pardon me;
His majesty hath straitly given in charge
That no man shall have private conference,
Of what degree soever, with his brother.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury,
You may partake of any thing we say:
We speak no treason, man: we say the king
Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen
Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous;
We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot,
A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue;
And that the queen's kindred are made gentle-folks:
How say you sir? Can you deny all this?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: With this, my lord, myself have nought to do.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Naught to do with mistress Shore! I tell thee, fellow,
He that doth naught with her, excepting one,
Were best he do it secretly, alone.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: What one, my lord?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Her husband, knave: wouldst thou betray me?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
I beseech your grace to pardon me, and withal
Forbear your conference with the noble duke.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
We are the queen's abjects, and must obey.
Brother, farewell: I will unto the king;
And whatsoever you will employ me in,
Were it to call King Edward's widow sister,
I will perform it to enfranchise you.
Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: I know it pleaseth neither of us well.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Well, your imprisonment shall not be long;
Meantime, have patience.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: I must perforce. Farewell.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
Simple, plain Clarence! I do love thee so,
That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,
If heaven will take the present at our hands.
But who comes here? the new-deliver'd Hastings?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: Good time of day unto my gracious lord!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
As much unto my good lord chamberlain!
Well are you welcome to the open air.
How hath your lordship brook'd imprisonment?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must:
But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks
That were the cause of my imprisonment.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
HASTINGS
sp.p:
More pity that the eagle should be mew'd,
While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: What news abroad?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Now, by Saint Paul, this news is bad indeed.
O, he hath kept an evil diet long,
And overmuch consumed his royal person:
'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.
What, is he in his bed?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: He is.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Go you before, and I will follow you.

He cannot live, I hope; and must not die
Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.
I'll in, to urge his hatred more to Clarence,
With lies well steel'd with weighty arguments;
And, if I fall not in my deep intent,
Clarence hath not another day to live:
Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,
And leave the world for me to bustle in!
For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.
What though I kill'd her husband and her father?
The readiest way to make the wench amends
Is to become her husband and her father:
The which will I; not all so much for love
As for another secret close intent,
By marrying her which I must reach unto.
But yet I run before my horse to market:
Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns:
When they are gone, then must I count my gains.

p.stage: Enter the corpse of KING HENRY the Sixth, Gentlemen with halberds to guard it; LADY ANNE being the mourner

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Set down, set down your honourable load,
If honour may be shrouded in a hearse,
Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament
The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
Poor key-cold figure of a holy king!
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster!
Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!
Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost,
To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne,
Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughter'd son,
Stabb'd by the selfsame hand that made these wounds!
Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life,
I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.
Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!
Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!
More direful hap betide that hated wretch,
That makes us wretched by the death of thee,
Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads,
Or any creeping venom'd thing that lives!
If ever he have child, abortive be it,
Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,
Whose ugly and unnatural aspect
May fright the hopeful mother at the view;
And that be heir to his unhappiness!
If ever he have wife, let her he made
A miserable by the death of him
As I am made by my poor lord and thee!
Come, now towards Chertsey with your holy load,
Taken from Paul's to be interred there;
And still, as you are weary of the weight,
Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
What black magician conjures up this fiend,
To stop devoted charitable deeds?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Villains, set down the corse; or, by Saint Paul,
I'll make a corse of him that disobeys.

sp.speaker: Gentleman
sp.p: My lord, stand back, and let the coffin pass.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Unmanner'd dog! stand thou, when I command:
Advance thy halbert higher than my breast,
Or, by Saint Paul, I'll strike thee to my foot,
And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
What, do you tremble? are you all afraid?
Alas, I blame you not; for you are mortal,
And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.
Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell!
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,
His soul thou canst not have; therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not;
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,
Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,
Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
O, gentlemen, see, see! dead Henry's wounds
Open their congeal'd mouths and bleed afresh!
Blush, Blush, thou lump of foul deformity;
For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood
From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;
Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural,
Provokes this deluge most unnatural.
O God, which this blood madest, revenge his death!
O earth, which this blood drink'st revenge his death!
Either heaven with lightning strike the
murderer dead,
Or earth, gape open wide and eat him quick,
As thou dost swallow up this good king's blood
Which his hell-govern'd arm hath butchered!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Lady, you know no rules of charity,
Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Villain, thou know'st no law of God nor man:
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: O wonderful, when devils tell the truth!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
More wonderful, when angels are so angry.
Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,
Of these supposed-evils, to give me leave,
By circumstance, but to acquit myself.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man,
For these known evils, but to give me leave,
By circumstance, to curse thy cursed self.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have
Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make
No excuse current, but to hang thyself.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: By such despair, I should accuse myself.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Say that I slew them not?

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Why, then they are not dead:
But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: I did not kill your husband.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Why, then he is alive.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Nay, he is dead; and slain by Edward's hand.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
In thy foul throat thou liest: Queen Margaret saw
Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood;
The which thou once didst bend against her breast,
But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I was provoked by her slanderous tongue,
which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.
Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries:
Didst thou not kill this king?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: I grant ye.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Dost grant me, hedgehog? then, God grant me too
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!
O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: The fitter for the King of heaven, that hath him.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither;
For he was fitter for that place than earth.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: And thou unfit for any place but hell.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Some dungeon.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Your bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I'll rest betide the chamber where thou liest!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: So will it, madam till I lie with you.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I hope so.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne,
To leave this keen encounter of our wits,
And fall somewhat into a slower method,
Is not the causer of the timeless deaths
Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,
As blameful as the executioner?

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Thou art the cause, and most accursed effect.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Your beauty was the cause of that effect;
Your beauty: which did haunt me in my sleep
To undertake the death of all the world,
So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide,
These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
These eyes could never endure sweet beauty's wreck;
You should not blemish it, if I stood by:
As all the world is cheered by the sun,
So I by that; it is my day, my life.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Curse not thyself, fair creature thou art both.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I would I were, to be revenged on thee.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
It is a quarrel most unnatural,
To be revenged on him that loveth you.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
It is a quarrel just and reasonable,
To be revenged on him that slew my husband.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband,
Did it to help thee to a better husband.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: His better doth not breathe upon the earth.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: He lives that loves thee better than he could.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Name him.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Why, that was he.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: The selfsame name, but one of better nature.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Where is he?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Here.
Why dost thou spit at me?

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Would it were mortal poison, for thy sake!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Never hung poison on a fouler toad.
Out of my sight! thou dost infect my eyes.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Would they were basilisks, to strike thee dead!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I would they were, that I might die at once;
For now they kill me with a living death.
Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,
Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops:
These eyes that never shed remorseful tear,
No, when my father York and Edward wept,
To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made
When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
Nor when thy warlike father, like a child,
Told the sad story of my father's death,
And twenty times made pause to sob and weep,
That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks
Like trees bedash'd with rain: in that sad time
My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;
And what these sorrows could not thence exhale,
Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.
I never sued to friend nor enemy;
My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word;
But now thy beauty is proposed my fee,
My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.

Teach not thy lips such scorn, for they were made
For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,
Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword;
Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom.
And let the soul forth that adoreth thee,
I lay it naked to the deadly stroke,
And humbly beg the death upon my knee.

p.stage: He lays his breast open: she offers at it with his sword

sp.p:
Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry,
But 'twas thy beauty that provoked me.
Nay, now dispatch; 'twas I that stabb'd young Edward,
But 'twas thy heavenly face that set me on.

p.stage: Here she lets fall the sword

sp.p: Take up the sword again, or take up me.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Arise, dissembler: though I wish thy death,
I will not be the executioner.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I have already.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Tush, that was in thy rage:
Speak it again, and, even with the word,
That hand, which, for thy love, did kill thy love,
Shall, for thy love, kill a far truer love;
To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I would I knew thy heart.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: 'Tis figured in my tongue.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: I fear me both are false.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Then never man was true.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Well, well, put up your sword.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Say, then, my peace is made.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: That shall you know hereafter.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: But shall I live in hope?

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: All men, I hope, live so.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: To take is not to give.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Look, how this ring encompasseth finger.
Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart;
Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.
And if thy poor devoted suppliant may
But beg one favour at thy gracious hand,
Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
That it would please thee leave these sad designs
To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,
And presently repair to Crosby Place;
Where, after I have solemnly interr'd
At Chertsey monastery this noble king,
And wet his grave with my repentant tears,
I will with all expedient duty see you:
For divers unknown reasons. I beseech you,
Grant me this boon.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
With all my heart; and much it joys me too,
To see you are become so penitent.
Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Bid me farewell.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE

p.stage: Exeunt LADY ANNE, TRESSEL, and BERKELEY

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Sirs, take up the corse.

sp.speaker: GENTLEMEN
sp.p: Towards Chertsey, noble lord?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: No, to White-Friars; there attend my coining.

Was ever woman in this humour woo'd?
Was ever woman in this humour won?
I'll have her; but I will not keep her long.
What! I, that kill'd her husband and his father,
To take her in her heart's extremest hate,
With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,
The bleeding witness of her hatred by;
Having God, her conscience, and these bars
against me,
And I nothing to back my suit at all,
But the plain devil and dissembling looks,
And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!
Ha!
Hath she forgot already that brave prince,
Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since,
Stabb'd in my angry mood at Tewksbury?
A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman,
Framed in the prodigality of nature,
Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal,
The spacious world cannot again afford
And will she yet debase her eyes on me,
That cropp'd the golden prime of this sweet prince,
And made her widow to a woful bed?
On me, whose all not equals Edward's moiety?
On me, that halt and am unshapen thus?
My dukedom to a beggarly denier,
I do mistake my person all this while:
Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot,
Myself to be a marvellous proper man.
I'll be at charges for a looking-glass,
And entertain some score or two of tailors,
To study fashions to adorn my body:
Since I am crept in favour with myself,
Will maintain it with some little cost.
But first I'll turn yon fellow in his grave;
And then return lamenting to my love.
Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,
That I may see my shadow as I pass.

p.stage: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, RIVERS, and GREY

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
Have patience, madam: there's no doubt his majesty
Will soon recover his accustom'd health.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.p:
In that you brook it in, it makes him worse:
Therefore, for God's sake, entertain good comfort,
And cheer his grace with quick and merry words.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: If he were dead, what would betide of me?

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: No other harm but loss of such a lord.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: The loss of such a lord includes all harm.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.p:
The heavens have bless'd you with a goodly son,
To be your comforter when he is gone.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Oh, he is young and his minority
Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester,
A man that loves not me, nor none of you.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Is it concluded that he shall be protector?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
It is determined, not concluded yet:
But so it must be, if the king miscarry.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.p: Here come the lords of Buckingham and Derby.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Good time of day unto your royal grace!

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p: God make your majesty joyful as you have been!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
The Countess Richmond, good my Lord of Derby.
To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.
Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she's your wife,
And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured
I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p:
I do beseech you, either not believe
The envious slanders of her false accusers;
Or, if she be accused in true report,
Bear with her weakness, which, I think proceeds
From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Saw you the king to-day, my Lord of Derby?

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p:
But now the Duke of Buckingham and I
Are come from visiting his majesty.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: What likelihood of his amendment, lords?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Madam, good hope; his grace speaks cheerfully.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: God grant him health! Did you confer with him?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Madam, we did: he desires to make atonement
Betwixt the Duke of Gloucester and your brothers,
And betwixt them and my lord chamberlain;
And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Would all were well! but that will never be
I fear our happiness is at the highest.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
They do me wrong, and I will not endure it:
Who are they that complain unto the king,
That I, forsooth, am stern, and love them not?
By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly
That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours.
Because I cannot flatter and speak fair,
Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog,
Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,
I must be held a rancorous enemy.
Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,
But thus his simple truth must be abused
By silken, sly, insinuating Jacks?

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.
When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong?
Or thee? or thee? or any of your faction?
A plague upon you all! His royal person,—
Whom God preserve better than you would wish!—
Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing-while,
But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.
The king, of his own royal disposition,
And not provoked by any suitor else;
Aiming, belike, at your interior hatred,
Which in your outward actions shows itself
Against my kindred, brothers, and myself,
Makes him to send; that thereby he may gather
The ground of your ill-will, and so remove it.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I cannot tell: the world is grown so bad,
That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch:
Since every Jack became a gentleman
There's many a gentle person made a Jack.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Come, come, we know your meaning, brother
Gloucester;
You envy my advancement and my friends':
God grant we never may have need of you!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Meantime, God grants that we have need of you:
Your brother is imprison'd by your means,
Myself disgraced, and the nobility
Held in contempt; whilst many fair promotions
Are daily given to ennoble those
That scarce, some two days since, were worth a noble.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
By Him that raised me to this careful height
From that contented hap which I enjoy'd,
I never did incense his majesty
Against the Duke of Clarence, but have been
An earnest advocate to plead for him.
My lord, you do me shameful injury,
Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
You may deny that you were not the cause
Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: She may, my lord, for—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
She may, Lord Rivers! why, who knows not so?
She may do more, sir, than denying that:
She may help you to many fair preferments,
And then deny her aiding hand therein,
And lay those honours on your high deserts.
What may she not? She may, yea, marry, may she—

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: What, marry, may she?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
What, marry, may she! marry with a king,
A bachelor, a handsome stripling too:
I wis your grandam had a worser match.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne
Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs:
By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty
With those gross taunts I often have endured.
I had rather be a country servant-maid
Than a great queen, with this condition,
To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at:
Small joy have I in being England's queen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
And lessen'd be that small, God, I beseech thee!
Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
What! threat you me with telling of the king?
Tell him, and spare not: look, what I have said
I will avouch in presence of the king:
I dare adventure to be sent to the Tower.
'Tis time to speak; my pains are quite forgot.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Out, devil! I remember them too well:
Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower,
And Edward, my poor son, at Tewksbury.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Ere you were queen, yea, or your husband king,
I was a pack-horse in his great affairs;
A weeder-out of his proud adversaries,
A liberal rewarder of his friends:
To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: Yea, and much better blood than his or thine.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
In all which time you and your husband Grey
Were factious for the house of Lancaster;
And, Rivers, so were you. Was not your husband
In Margaret's battle at Saint Alban's slain?
Let me put in your minds, if you forget,
What you have been ere now, and what you are;
Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: A murderous villain, and so still thou art.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Poor Clarence did forsake his father, Warwick;
Yea, and forswore himself,—which Jesu pardon!—

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: Which God revenge!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world,
Thou cacodemon! there thy kingdom is.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days
Which here you urge to prove us enemies,
We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king:
So should we you, if you should be our king.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
If I should be! I had rather be a pedlar:
Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
As little joy, my lord, as you suppose
You should enjoy, were you this country's king,
As little joy may you suppose in me.
That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out
In sharing that which you have pill'd from me!
Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
If not, that, I being queen, you bow like subjects,
Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels?
O gentle villain, do not turn away!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
But repetition of what thou hast marr'd;
That will I make before I let thee go.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Wert thou not banished on pain of death?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
I was; but I do find more pain in banishment
Than death can yield me here by my abode.
A husband and a son thou owest to me;
And thou a kingdom; all of you allegiance:
The sorrow that I have, by right is yours,
And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
The curse my noble father laid on thee,
When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper
And with thy scorns drew'st rivers from his eyes,
And then, to dry them, gavest the duke a clout
Steep'd in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland—
His curses, then from bitterness of soul
Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee;
And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: So just is God, to right the innocent.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
O, 'twas the foulest deed to slay that babe,
And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
What were you snarling all before I came,
Ready to catch each other by the throat,
And turn you all your hatred now on me?
Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?
That Henry's death, my lovely Edward's death,
Their kingdom's loss, my woful banishment,
Could all but answer for that peevish brat?
Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?
Why, then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!
If not by war, by surfeit die your king,
As ours by murder, to make him a king!
Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales,
For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales,
Die in his youth by like untimely violence!
Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen,
Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self!
Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's loss;
And see another, as I see thee now,
Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stall'd in mine!
Long die thy happy days before thy death;
And, after many lengthen'd hours of grief,
Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!
Rivers and Dorset, you were standers by,
And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son
Was stabb'd with bloody daggers: God, I pray him,
That none of you may live your natural age,
But by some unlook'd accident cut off!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Have done thy charm, thou hateful wither'd hag!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
And leave out thee? stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.
If heaven have any grievous plague in store
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,
O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe,
And then hurl down their indignation
On thee, the troubler of the poor world's peace!
The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul!
Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest,
And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends!
No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine,
Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream
Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils!
Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!
Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity
The slave of nature and the son of hell!
Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb!
Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins!
Thou rag of honour! thou detested—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Margaret.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: Richard!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: I call thee not.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I cry thee mercy then, for I had thought
That thou hadst call'd me all these bitter names.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Why, so I did; but look'd for no reply.
O, let me make the period to my curse!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: 'Tis done by me, and ends in 'Margaret.'

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune!
Why strew'st thou sugar on that bottled spider,
Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
Fool, fool! thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.
The time will come when thou shalt wish for me
To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,
Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
To serve me well, you all should do me duty,
Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects:
O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Peace, master marquess, you are malapert:
Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce current.
O, that your young nobility could judge
What 'twere to lose it, and be miserable!
They that stand high have many blasts to shake them;
And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Good counsel, marry: learn it, learn it, marquess.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: It toucheth you, my lord, as much as me.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Yea, and much more: but I was born so high,
Our aery buildeth in the cedar's top,
And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
And turns the sun to shade; alas! alas!
Witness my son, now in the shade of death;
Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath
Hath in eternal darkness folded up.
Your aery buildeth in our aery's nest.
O God, that seest it, do not suffer it!
As it was won with blood, lost be it so!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Have done! for shame, if not for charity.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Urge neither charity nor shame to me:
Uncharitably with me have you dealt,
And shamefully by you my hopes are butcher'd.
My charity is outrage, life my shame
And in that shame still live my sorrow's rage.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Have done, have done.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
O princely Buckingham I'll kiss thy hand,
In sign of league and amity with thee:
Now fair befal thee and thy noble house!
Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,
Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Nor no one here; for curses never pass
The lips of those that breathe them in the air.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
I'll not believe but they ascend the sky,
And there awake God's gentle-sleeping peace.
O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog!
Look, when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites,
His venom tooth will rankle to the death:
Have not to do with him, beware of him;
Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him,
And all their ministers attend on him.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: What doth she say, my Lord of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel?
And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?
O, but remember this another day,
When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,
And say poor Margaret was a prophetess!
Live each of you the subjects to his hate,
And he to yours, and all of you to God's!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: And so doth mine: I muse why she's at liberty.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I cannot blame her: by God's holy mother,
She hath had too much wrong; and I repent
My part thereof that I have done to her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: I never did her any, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
But you have all the vantage of her wrong.
I was too hot to do somebody good,
That is too cold in thinking of it now.
Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid,
He is frank'd up to fatting for his pains
God pardon them that are the cause of it!

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion,
To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: So do I ever:

being well-advised.
For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
Madam, his majesty doth call for you,
And for your grace; and you, my noble lords.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Catesby, we come. Lords, will you go with us?

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Madam, we will attend your grace.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.
The secret mischiefs that I set abroach
I lay unto the grievous charge of others.
Clarence, whom I, indeed, have laid in darkness,
I do beweep to many simple gulls
Namely, to Hastings, Derby, Buckingham;
And say it is the queen and her allies
That stir the king against the duke my brother.
Now, they believe it; and withal whet me
To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey:
But then I sigh; and, with a piece of scripture,
Tell them that God bids us do good for evil:
And thus I clothe my naked villany
With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ;
And seem a saint, when most I play the devil.

But, soft! here come my executioners.
How now, my hardy, stout resolved mates!
Are you now going to dispatch this deed?

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
We are, my lord; and come to have the warrant
That we may be admitted where he is.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Well thought upon; I have it here about me.

When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.
But, sirs, be sudden in the execution,
Withal obdurate, do not hear him plead;
For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps
May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Tush!
Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate;
Talkers are no good doers: be assured
We come to use our hands and not our tongues.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
First Murderer
sp.p: We will, my noble lord.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: Why looks your grace so heavily today?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
O, I have pass'd a miserable night,
So full of ugly sights, of ghastly dreams,
That, as I am a Christian faithful man,
I would not spend another such a night,
Though 'twere to buy a world of happy days,
So full of dismal terror was the time!

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: What was your dream? I long to hear you tell it.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower,
And was embark'd to cross to Burgundy;
And, in my company, my brother Gloucester;
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk
Upon the hatches: thence we looked toward England,
And cited up a thousand fearful times,
During the wars of York and Lancaster
That had befall'n us. As we paced along
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,
Methought that Gloucester stumbled; and, in falling,
Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard,
Into the tumbling billows of the main.
Lord, Lord! methought, what pain it was to drown!
What dreadful noise of waters in mine ears!
What ugly sights of death within mine eyes!
Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks;
Ten thousand men that fishes gnaw'd upon;
Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,
Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,
All scatter'd in the bottom of the sea:
Some lay in dead men's skulls; and, in those holes
Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept,
As 'twere in scorn of eyes, reflecting gems,
Which woo'd the slimy bottom of the deep,
And mock'd the dead bones that lay scatter'd by.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
Had you such leisure in the time of death
To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Methought I had; and often did I strive
To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood
Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth
To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;
But smother'd it within my panting bulk,
Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: Awaked you not with this sore agony?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
O, no, my dream was lengthen'd after life;
O, then began the tempest to my soul,
Who pass'd, methought, the melancholy flood,
With that grim ferryman which poets write of,
Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.
The first that there did greet my stranger soul,
Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick;
Who cried aloud, 'What scourge for perjury
Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?'
And so he vanish'd: then came wandering by
A shadow like an angel, with bright hair
Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud,
'Clarence is come; false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,
That stabb'd me in the field by Tewksbury;
Seize on him, Furies, take him to your torments!'
With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends
Environ'd me about, and howled in mine ears
Such hideous cries, that with the very noise
I trembling waked, and for a season after
Could not believe but that I was in hell,
Such terrible impression made the dream.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
No marvel, my lord, though it affrighted you;
I promise, I am afraid to hear you tell it.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
O Brakenbury, I have done those things,
Which now bear evidence against my soul,
For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me!
O God! if my deep prayers cannot appease thee,
But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds,
Yet execute thy wrath in me alone,
O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!
I pray thee, gentle keeper, stay by me;
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: I will, my lord: God give your grace good rest!

Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,
Makes the night morning, and the noon-tide night.
Princes have but their tides for their glories,
An outward honour for an inward toil;
And, for unfelt imagination,
They often feel a world of restless cares:
So that, betwixt their tides and low names,
There's nothing differs but the outward fame.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Ho! who's here?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: In God's name what are you, and how came you hither?

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: Yea, are you so brief?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious. Show
him our commission; talk no more.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
I am, in this, commanded to deliver
The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands:
I will not reason what is meant hereby,
Because I will be guiltless of the meaning.
Here are the keys, there sits the duke asleep:
I'll to the king; and signify to him
That thus I have resign'd my charge to you.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: What, shall we stab him as he sleeps?

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: No; then he will say 'twas done cowardly, when he wakes.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
When he wakes! why, fool, he shall never wake till
the judgment-day.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Why, then he will say we stabbed him sleeping.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
The urging of that word 'judgment' hath bred a kind
of remorse in me.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: What, art thou afraid?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
Not to kill him, having a warrant for it; but to be
damned for killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: I thought thou hadst been resolute.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: So I am, to let him live.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Back to the Duke of Gloucester, tell him so.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
I pray thee, stay a while: I hope my holy humour
will change; 'twas wont to hold me but while one
would tell twenty.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: How dost thou feel thyself now?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
'Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet
within me.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Remember our reward, when the deed is done.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: 'Zounds, he dies: I had forgot the reward.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Where is thy conscience now?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: In the Duke of Gloucester's purse.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
So when he opens his purse to give us our reward,
thy conscience flies out.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: Let it go; there's few or none will entertain it.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: How if it come to thee again?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
I'll not meddle with it: it is a dangerous thing: it
makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal, but it
accuseth him; he cannot swear, but it cheques him;
he cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it
detects him: 'tis a blushing shamefast spirit that
mutinies in a man's bosom; it fills one full of
obstacles: it made me once restore a purse of gold
that I found; it beggars any man that keeps it: it
is turned out of all towns and cities for a
dangerous thing; and every man that means to live
well endeavours to trust to himself and to live
without it.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
'Zounds, it is even now at my elbow, persuading me
not to kill the duke.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
Take the devil in thy mind, and relieve him not: he
would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Tut, I am strong-framed, he cannot prevail with me,
I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
Spoke like a tail fellow that respects his
reputation. Come, shall we to this gear?

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy
sword, and then we will chop him in the malmsey-butt
in the next room.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: O excellent devise! make a sop of him.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Hark! he stirs: shall I strike?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: No, first let's reason with him.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: Where art thou, keeper? give me a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Second murderer
sp.p: You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: In God's name, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: A man, as you are.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: But not, as I am, royal.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: Nor you, as we are, loyal.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: My voice is now the king's, my looks mine own.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak!
Your eyes do menace me: why look you pale?
Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: To, to, to—

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: To murder me?

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,
And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Offended us you have not, but the king.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: I shall be reconciled to him again.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: Never, my lord; therefore prepare to die.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Are you call'd forth from out a world of men
To slay the innocent? What is my offence?
Where are the evidence that do accuse me?
What lawful quest have given their verdict up
Unto the frowning judge? or who pronounced
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death?
Before I be convict by course of law,
To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
I charge you, as you hope to have redemption
By Christ's dear blood shed for our grievous sins,
That you depart and lay no hands on me
The deed you undertake is damnable.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: What we will do, we do upon command.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: And he that hath commanded is the king.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings
Hath in the tables of his law commanded
That thou shalt do no murder: and wilt thou, then,
Spurn at his edict and fulfil a man's?
Take heed; for he holds vengeance in his hands,
To hurl upon their heads that break his law.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
And that same vengeance doth he hurl on thee,
For false forswearing and for murder too:
Thou didst receive the holy sacrament,
To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
And, like a traitor to the name of God,
Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade
Unrip'dst the bowels of thy sovereign's son.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
How canst thou urge God's dreadful law to us,
When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Alas! for whose sake did I that ill deed?
For Edward, for my brother, for his sake: Why, sirs,
He sends ye not to murder me for this
For in this sin he is as deep as I.
If God will be revenged for this deed.
O, know you yet, he doth it publicly,
Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm;
He needs no indirect nor lawless course
To cut off those that have offended him.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Who made thee, then, a bloody minister,
When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet,
That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: My brother's love, the devil, and my rage.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault,
Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Oh, if you love my brother, hate not me;
I am his brother, and I love him well.
If you be hired for meed, go back again,
And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,
Who shall reward you better for my life
Than Edward will for tidings of my death.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: You are deceived, your brother Gloucester hates you.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear:
Go you to him from me.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Ay, so we will.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Tell him, when that our princely father York
Bless'd his three sons with his victorious arm,
And charged us from his soul to love each other,
He little thought of this divided friendship:
Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Ay, millstones; as be lesson'd us to weep.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: O, do not slander him, for he is kind.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
Right,
As snow in harvest. Thou deceivest thyself:
'Tis he that sent us hither now to slaughter thee.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
It cannot be; for when I parted with him,
He hugg'd me in his arms, and swore, with sobs,
That he would labour my delivery.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
Why, so he doth, now he delivers thee
From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul,
To counsel me to make my peace with God,
And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind,
That thou wilt war with God by murdering me?
Ah, sirs, consider, he that set you on
To do this deed will hate you for the deed.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: What shall we do?

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p: Relent, and save your souls.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Relent! 'tis cowardly and womanish.

sp.speaker: CLARENCE
sp.p:
Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.
Which of you, if you were a prince's son,
Being pent from liberty, as I am now,
if two such murderers as yourselves came to you,
Would not entreat for life?
My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:
O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,
Come thou on my side, and entreat for me,
As you would beg, were you in my distress
A begging prince what beggar pities not?

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p: Look behind you, my lord.

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p: Take that, and that: if all this will not do,
I'll drown you in the malmsey-butt within.

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
sp.p:
A bloody deed, and desperately dispatch'd!
How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands
Of this most grievous guilty murder done!

sp.speaker: First Murderer
sp.p:
How now! what mean'st thou, that thou help'st me not?
By heavens, the duke shall know how slack thou art!

sp.speaker: Second Murderer
First Murderer
sp.p:
So do not I: go, coward as thou art.
Now must I hide his body in some hole,
Until the duke take order for his burial:
And when I have my meed, I must away;
For this will out, and here I must not stay.

p.stage: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV sick, QUEEN ELIZABETH, DORSET, RIVERS, HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
Why, so: now have I done a good day's work:
You peers, continue this united league:
I every day expect an embassage
From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;
And now in peace my soul shall part to heaven,
Since I have set my friends at peace on earth.
Rivers and Hastings, take each other's hand;
Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate:
And with my hand I seal my true heart's love.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: So thrive I, as I truly swear the like!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
Take heed you dally not before your king;
Lest he that is the supreme King of kings
Confound your hidden falsehood, and award
Either of you to be the other's end.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love!

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: And I, as I love Hastings with my heart!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Here, Hastings; I will never more remember
Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p: Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p:
This interchange of love, I here protest,
Upon my part shall be unviolable.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: And so swear I, my lord

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league
With thy embracements to my wife's allies,
And make me happy in your unity.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate
On you or yours,

but with all duteous love
Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me
With hate in those where I expect most love!
When I have most need to employ a friend,
And most assured that he is a friend
Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile,
Be he unto me! this do I beg of God,
When I am cold in zeal to yours.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,
is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.
There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here,
To make the perfect period of this peace.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: And, in good time, here comes the noble duke.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen:
And, princely peers, a happy time of day!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
Happy, indeed, as we have spent the day.
Brother, we done deeds of charity;
Made peace enmity, fair love of hate,
Between these swelling wrong-incensed peers.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege:
Amongst this princely heap, if any here,
By false intelligence, or wrong surmise,
Hold me a foe;
If I unwittingly, or in my rage,
Have aught committed that is hardly borne
By any in this presence, I desire
To reconcile me to his friendly peace:
'Tis death to me to be at enmity;
I hate it, and desire all good men's love.
First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,
Which I will purchase with my duteous service;
Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,
If ever any grudge were lodged between us;
Of you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, of you;
That without desert have frown'd on me;
Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.
I do not know that Englishman alive
With whom my soul is any jot at odds
More than the infant that is born to-night
I thank my God for my humility.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
A holy day shall this be kept hereafter:
I would to God all strifes were well compounded.
My sovereign liege, I do beseech your majesty
To take our brother Clarence to your grace.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Why, madam, have I offer'd love for this
To be so bouted in this royal presence?
Who knows not that the noble duke is dead?
You do him injury to scorn his corse.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Who knows not he is dead! who knows he is?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: All seeing heaven, what a world is this!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p:
Ay, my good lord; and no one in this presence
But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p: Is Clarence dead? the order was reversed.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
But he, poor soul, by your first order died,
And that a winged Mercury did bear:
Some tardy cripple bore the countermand,
That came too lag to see him buried.
God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,
Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood,
Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,
And yet go current from suspicion!

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: A boon, my sovereign, for my service done!

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p: I pray thee, peace: my soul is full of sorrow.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: I will not rise, unless your highness grant.

sp.speaker: KING EDWARD IV
sp.p: Then speak at once what is it thou demand'st.

sp.speaker: DORSET
KING EDWARD IV
sp.p:
Have a tongue to doom my brother's death,
And shall the same give pardon to a slave?
My brother slew no man; his fault was thought,
And yet his punishment was cruel death.
Who sued to me for him? who, in my rage,
Kneel'd at my feet, and bade me be advised
Who spake of brotherhood? who spake of love?
Who told me how the poor soul did forsake
The mighty Warwick, and did fight for me?
Who told me, in the field by Tewksbury
When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,
And said, 'Dear brother, live, and be a king'?
Who told me, when we both lay in the field
Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me
Even in his own garments, and gave himself,
All thin and naked, to the numb cold night?
All this from my remembrance brutish wrath
Sinfully pluck'd, and not a man of you
Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your carters or your waiting-vassals
Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced
The precious image of our dear Redeemer,
You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon;
And I unjustly too, must grant it you
But for my brother not a man would speak,
Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself
For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all
Have been beholding to him in his life;
Yet none of you would once plead for his life.
O God, I fear thy justice will take hold
On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this!
Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.
Oh, poor Clarence!

p.stage: Exeunt some with KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN MARGARET

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
This is the fruit of rashness! Mark'd you not
How that the guilty kindred of the queen
Look'd pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?
O, they did urge it still unto the king!
God will revenge it. But come, let us in,
To comfort Edward with our company.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: We wait upon your grace.

p.stage: Enter the DUCHESS OF YORK, with the two children of CLARENCE

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Tell me, good grandam, is our father dead?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: No, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast,
And cry 'O Clarence, my unhappy son!'

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p:
Why do you look on us, and shake your head,
And call us wretches, orphans, castaways
If that our noble father be alive?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
Boy
sp.p:
Then, grandam, you conclude that he is dead.
The king my uncle is to blame for this:
God will revenge it; whom I will importune
With daily prayers all to that effect.

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p: And so will I.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Peace, children, peace! the king doth love you well:
Incapable and shallow innocents,
You cannot guess who caused your father's death.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Grandam, we can; for my good uncle Gloucester
Told me, the king, provoked by the queen,
Devised impeachments to imprison him :
And when my uncle told me so, he wept,
And hugg'd me in his arm, and kindly kiss'd my cheek;
Bade me rely on him as on my father,
And he would love me dearly as his child.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Oh, that deceit should steal such gentle shapes,
And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile!
He is my son; yea, and therein my shame;
Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Ay, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: I cannot think it. Hark! what noise is this?

p.stage: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, with her hair about her ears; RIVERS, and DORSET after her

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Oh, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,
To chide my fortune, and torment myself?
I'll join with black despair against my soul,
And to myself become an enemy.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: What means this scene of rude impatience?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
To make an act of tragic violence:
Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.
Why grow the branches now the root is wither'd?
Why wither not the leaves the sap being gone?
If you will live, lament; if die, be brief,
That our swift-winged souls may catch the king's;
Or, like obedient subjects, follow him
To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow
As I had title in thy noble husband!
I have bewept a worthy husband's death,
And lived by looking on his images:
But now two mirrors of his princely semblance
Are crack'd in pieces by malignant death,
And I for comfort have but one false glass,
Which grieves me when I see my shame in him.
Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother,
And hast the comfort of thy children left thee:
But death hath snatch'd my husband from mine arms,
And pluck'd two crutches from my feeble limbs,
Edward and Clarence. O, what cause have I,
Thine being but a moiety of my grief,
To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p:
Good aunt, you wept not for our father's death;
How can we aid you with our kindred tears?

sp.speaker: Girl
sp.p:
Our fatherless distress was left unmoan'd;
Your widow-dolour likewise be unwept!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Give me no help in lamentation;
I am not barren to bring forth complaints
All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,
That I, being govern'd by the watery moon,
May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world!
Oh for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Oh for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: What stay had I but Edward? and he's gone.

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: What stay had we but Clarence? and he's gone.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: What stays had I but they? and they are gone.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Was never widow had so dear a loss!

sp.speaker: Children
sp.p: Were never orphans had so dear a loss!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Was never mother had so dear a loss!
Alas, I am the mother of these moans!
Their woes are parcell'd, mine are general.
She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;
I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:
These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;
I for an Edward weep, so do not they:
Alas, you three, on me, threefold distress'd,
Pour all your tears! I am your sorrow's nurse,
And I will pamper it with lamentations.

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p:
Comfort, dear mother: God is much displeased
That you take with unthankfulness, his doing:
In common worldly things, 'tis call'd ungrateful,
With dull unwilligness to repay a debt
Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;
Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,
For it requires the royal debt it lent you.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,
Of the young prince your son: send straight for him
Let him be crown'd; in him your comfort lives:
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave,
And plant your joys in living Edward's throne.

p.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, and RATCLIFF

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind,
Love, charity, obedience, and true duty!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Amen; and make me die a good old man!
That is the butt-end of a mother's blessing:
I marvel why her grace did leave it out.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers,
That bear this mutual heavy load of moan,
Now cheer each other in each other's love
Though we have spent our harvest of this king,
We are to reap the harvest of his son.
The broken rancour of your high-swoln hearts,
But lately splinter'd, knit, and join'd together,
Must gently be preserved, cherish'd, and kept:
Me seemeth good, that, with some little train,
Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd
Hither to London, to be crown'd our king.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p: Why with some little train, my Lord of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Marry, my lord, lest, by a multitude,
The new-heal'd wound of malice should break out,
Which would be so much the more dangerous
By how much the estate is green and yet ungovern'd:
Where every horse bears his commanding rein,
And may direct his course as please himself,
As well the fear of harm, as harm apparent,
In my opinion, ought to be prevented.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I hope the king made peace with all of us
And the compact is firm and true in me.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
And so in me; and so, I think, in all:
Yet, since it is but green, it should be put
To no apparent likelihood of breach,
Which haply by much company might be urged:
Therefore I say with noble Buckingham,
That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: And so say I.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Then be it so; and go we to determine
Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.
Madam, and you, my mother, will you go
To give your censures in this weighty business?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: With all our harts.

p.stage: Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM and GLOUCESTER

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
My lord, whoever journeys to the Prince,
For God's sake, let not us two be behind;
For, by the way, I'll sort occasion,
As index to the story we late talk'd of,
To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
My other self, my counsel's consistory,
My oracle, my prophet! My dear cousin,
I, like a child, will go by thy direction.
Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: Neighbour, well met: whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p:
I promise you, I scarcely know myself:
Hear you the news abroad?

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: Ay, that the king is dead.

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p:
Bad news, by'r lady; seldom comes the better:
I fear, I fear 'twill prove a troublous world.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p: Neighbours, God speed!

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: Give you good morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p: Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p: Ay, sir, it is too true; God help the while!

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p: Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: No, no; by God's good grace his son shall reign.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p: Woe to the land that's govern'd by a child!

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p:
In him there is a hope of government,
That in his nonage council under him,
And in his full and ripen'd years himself,
No doubt, shall then and till then govern well.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p:
So stood the state when Henry the Sixth
Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p:
Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot;
For then this land was famously enrich'd
With politic grave counsel; then the king
Had virtuous uncles to protect his grace.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p:
Better it were they all came by the father,
Or by the father there were none at all;
For emulation now, who shall be nearest,
Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.
O, full of danger is the Duke of Gloucester!
And the queen's sons and brothers haught and proud:
And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,
This sickly land might solace as before.

sp.speaker: First Citizen
sp.p: Come, come, we fear the worst; all shall be well.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
Second Citizen
sp.p:
Truly, the souls of men are full of dread:
Ye cannot reason almost with a man
That looks not heavily and full of fear.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p:
Before the times of change, still is it so:
By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust
Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see
The waters swell before a boisterous storm.
But leave it all to God. whither away?

sp.speaker: Second Citizen
sp.p: Marry, we were sent for to the justices.

sp.speaker: Third Citizen
sp.p: And so was I: I'll bear you company.

p.stage: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK, young YORK, QUEEN ELIZABETH, and the DUCHESS OF YORK

sp.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
I long with all my heart to see the prince:
I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
But I hear, no; they say my son of York
Hath almost overta'en him in his growth.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: Ay, mother; but I would not have it so.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Why, my young cousin, it is good to grow.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
Grandam, one night, as we did sit at supper,
My uncle Rivers talk'd how I did grow
More than my brother: 'Ay,' quoth my uncle
Gloucester,
'Small herbs have grace, great weeds do grow apace:'
And since, methinks, I would not grow so fast,
Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold
In him that did object the same to thee;
He was the wretched'st thing when he was young,
So long a-growing and so leisurely,
That, if this rule were true, he should be gracious.

sp.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
sp.p: Why, madam, so, no doubt, he is.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I hope he is; but yet let mothers doubt.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
Now, by my troth, if I had been remember'd,
I could have given my uncle's grace a flout,
To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: How, my pretty York? I pray thee, let me hear it.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast
That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old
'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I pray thee, pretty York, who told thee this?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: Grandam, his nurse.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: His nurse! why, she was dead ere thou wert born.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: If 'twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: A parlous boy: go to, you are too shrewd.

sp.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
sp.p: Good madam, be not angry with the child.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Pitchers have ears.

sp.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
sp.p: Here comes a messenger. What news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Such news, my lord, as grieves me to unfold.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: How fares the prince?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Well, madam, and in health.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: What is thy news then?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,
With them Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Who hath committed them?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
The mighty dukes
Gloucester and Buckingham.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: For what offence?

sp.speaker: Messenger
QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Ay me, I see the downfall of our house!
The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind;
Insulting tyranny begins to jet
Upon the innocent and aweless throne:
Welcome, destruction, death, and massacre!
I see, as in a map, the end of all.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Accursed and unquiet wrangling days,
How many of you have mine eyes beheld!
My husband lost his life to get the crown;
And often up and down my sons were toss'd,
For me to joy and weep their gain and loss:
And being seated, and domestic broils
Clean over-blown, themselves, the conquerors.
Make war upon themselves; blood against blood,
Self against self: O, preposterous
And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen;
Or let me die, to look on death no more!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Come, come, my boy; we will to sanctuary.
Madam, farewell.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I'll go along with you.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: You have no cause.

sp.speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK
sp.p:
My gracious lady, go;
And thither bear your treasure and your goods.
For my part, I'll resign unto your grace
The seal I keep: and so betide to me
As well I tender you and all of yours!
Come, I'll conduct you to the sanctuary.

p.stage: The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE EDWARD, GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM, CARDINAL, CATESBY, and others

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign
The weary way hath made you melancholy.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
No, uncle; but our crosses on the way
Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy
I want more uncles here to welcome me.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years
Hath not yet dived into the world's deceit
Nor more can you distinguish of a man
Than of his outward show; which, God he knows,
Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.
Those uncles which you want were dangerous;
Your grace attended to their sugar'd words,
But look'd not on the poison of their hearts :
God keep you from them, and from such false friends!

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: God keep me from false friends! but they were none.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.

p.stage: Enter the Lord Mayor and his train

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: God bless your grace with health and happy days!

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
I thank you, good my lord; and thank you all.
I thought my mother, and my brother York,
Would long ere this have met us on the way
Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not
To tell us whether they will come or no!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: And, in good time, here comes the sweating lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: Welcome, my lord: what, will our mother come?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
On what occasion, God he knows, not I,
The queen your mother, and your brother York,
Have taken sanctuary: the tender prince
Would fain have come with me to meet your grace,
But by his mother was perforce withheld.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Is this of hers! Lord cardinal, will your grace
Persuade the queen to send the Duke of York
Unto his princely brother presently?
If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,
And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p:
My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory
Can from his mother win the Duke of York,
Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessed sanctuary! not for all this land
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
You are too senseless—obstinate, my lord,
Too ceremonious and traditional
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,
You break not sanctuary in seizing him.
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place,
And those who have the wit to claim the place:
This prince hath neither claim'd it nor deserved it;
And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it:
Then, taking him from thence that is not there,
You break no privilege nor charter there.
Oft have I heard of sanctuary men;
But sanctuary children ne'er till now.

sp.speaker: CARDINAL
sp.p:
My lord, you shall o'er-rule my mind for once.
Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: I go, my lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.

Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,
Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Where it seems best unto your royal self.
If I may counsel you, some day or two
Your highness shall repose you at the Tower:
Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit
For your best health and recreation.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
I do not like the Tower, of any place.
Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
He did, my gracious lord, begin that place;
Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
Is it upon record, or else reported
Successively from age to age, he built it?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Upon record, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
But say, my lord, it were not register'd,
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
As 'twere retail'd to all posterity,
Even to the general all-ending day.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
So wise so young, they say, do never
live long.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: What say you, uncle?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: I say, without characters, fame lives long.

Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,
I moralize two meanings in one word.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: What, my gracious lord?

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
An if I live until I be a man,
I'll win our ancient right in France again,
Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

p.stage: Enter young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Now, in good time, here comes the Duke of York.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: Richard of York! how fares our loving brother?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: Well, my dread lord; so must I call you now.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours:
Too late he died that might have kept that title,
Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,
You said that idle weeds are fast in growth
The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: He hath, my lord.
