sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: And therefore is he idle?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: Then is he more beholding to you than I.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
He may command me as my sovereign;
But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: My dagger, little cousin? with all my heart.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: A beggar, brother?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
Of my kind uncle, that I know will give;
And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: A greater gift than that I'll give my cousin.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: A greater gift! O, that's the sword to it.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: A gentle cousin, were it light enough.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
O, then, I see, you will part but with light gifts;
In weightier things you'll say a beggar nay.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: It is too heavy for your grace to wear.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: What, would you have my weapon, little lord?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: Little.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
My Lord of York will still be cross in talk:
Uncle, your grace knows how to bear with him.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me:
Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me;
Because that I am little, like an ape,
He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!
To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,
He prettily and aptly taunts himself:
So cunning and so young is wonderful.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
My lord, will't please you pass along?
Myself and my good cousin Buckingham
Will to your mother, to entreat of her
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: My lord protector needs will have it so.

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p: I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Why, what should you fear?

sp.speaker: YORK
sp.p:
Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost:
My grandam told me he was murdered there.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p: I fear no uncles dead.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Nor none that live, I hope.

sp.speaker: PRINCE EDWARD
sp.p:
An if they live, I hope I need not fear.
But come, my lord; and with a heavy heart,
Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.

p.stage: A Sennet. Exeunt all but GLOUCESTER, BUCKINGHAM and CATESBY

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Think you, my lord, this little prating York
Was not incensed by his subtle mother
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Well, let them rest. Come hither, Catesby.
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend
As closely to conceal what we impart:
Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;
What think'st thou? is it not an easy matter
To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,
For the instalment of this noble duke
In the seat royal of this famous isle?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
He for his father's sake so loves the prince,
That he will not be won to aught against him.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: What think'st thou, then, of Stanley? what will he?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Well, then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,
And, as it were far off sound thou Lord Hastings,
How doth he stand affected to our purpose;
And summon him to-morrow to the Tower,
To sit about the coronation.
If thou dost find him tractable to us,
Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:
If he be leaden, icy-cold, unwilling,
Be thou so too; and so break off your talk,
And give us notice of his inclination:
For we to-morrow hold divided councils,
Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,
His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries
To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;
And bid my friend, for joy of this good news,
Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Good Catesby, go, effect this business soundly.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: My good lords both, with all the heed I may.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: You shall, my lord.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive
Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Chop off his head, man; somewhat we will do:
And, look, when I am king, claim thou of me
The earldom of Hereford, and the moveables
Whereof the king my brother stood possess'd.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: I'll claim that promise at your grace's hands.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
And look to have it yielded with all willingness.
Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards
We may digest our complots in some form.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: What, ho! my lord!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: Who knocks at the door?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: A messenger from the Lord Stanley.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: What is't o'clock?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: Upon the stroke of four.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
So it should seem by that I have to say.
First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: And then?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
And then he sends you word
He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm:
Besides, he says there are two councils held;
And that may be determined at the one
which may make you and him to rue at the other.
Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure,
If presently you will take horse with him,
And with all speed post with him toward the north,
To shun the danger that his soul divines.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;
Bid him not fear the separated councils
His honour and myself are at the one,
And at the other is my servant Catesby
Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us
Whereof I shall not have intelligence.
Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance:
And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fond
To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers
To fly the boar before the boar pursues,
Were to incense the boar to follow us
And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.
Go, bid thy master rise and come to me
And we will both together to the Tower,
Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring
What news, what news, in this our tottering state?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
HASTINGS
sp.p: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders
Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.
But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward
Upon his party for the gain thereof:
And thereupon he sends you this good news,
That this same very day your enemies,
The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,
Because they have been still mine enemies:
But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side,
To bar my master's heirs in true descent,
God knows I will not do it, to the death.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,
That they who brought me in my master's hate
I live to look upon their tragedy.
I tell thee, Catesby—

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: What, my lord?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Ere a fortnight make me elder,
I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,
When men are unprepared and look not for it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out
With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do
With some men else, who think themselves as safe
As thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dear
To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: The princes both make high account of you;
For they account his head upon the bridge.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: I know they do; and I have well deserved it.

Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man?
Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby:
You may jest on, but, by the holy rood,
I do not like these several councils, I.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
My lord,
I hold my life as dear as you do yours;
And never in my life, I do protest,
Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:
Think you, but that I know our state secure,
I would be so triumphant as I am?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,
Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure,
And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;
But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast.
This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt:
Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!
What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord?
To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

sp.speaker: LORD STANLEY
sp.p:
They, for their truth, might better wear their heads
Than some that have accused them wear their hats.
But come, my lord, let us away.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.
How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?

sp.speaker: Pursuivant
sp.p: The better that your lordship please to ask.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now
Than when I met thee last where now we meet:
Then was I going prisoner to the Tower,
By the suggestion of the queen's allies;
But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself—
This day those enemies are put to death,
And I in better state than e'er I was.

sp.speaker: Pursuivant
sp.p: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.

sp.speaker: Pursuivant
sp.p: God save your lordship!

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.p: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
BUCKINGHAM
HASTINGS
sp.p:
Good faith, and when I met this holy man,
Those men you talk of came into my mind.
What, go you toward the Tower?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay
I shall return before your lordship thence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
And supper too, although thou know'st it not.
Come, will you go?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: I'll wait upon your lordship.

p.stage: Enter RATCLIFF, with halberds, carrying RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN to death

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p: Come, bring forth the prisoners.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
Sir Richard Ratcliff, let me tell thee this:
To-day shalt thou behold a subject die
For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.p:
God keep the prince from all the pack of you!
A knot you are of damned blood-suckers!

sp.speaker: VAUGHAN
sp.p: You live that shall cry woe for this after.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p: Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,
Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
Within the guilty closure of thy walls
Richard the second here was hack'd to death;
And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,
We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.

sp.speaker: GREY
sp.p:
Now Margaret's curse is fall'n upon our heads,
For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
Then cursed she Hastings, then cursed she Buckingham,
Then cursed she Richard. O, remember, God
To hear her prayers for them, as now for us
And for my sister and her princely sons,
Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,
Which, as thou know'st, unjustly must be spilt.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p: Make haste; the hour of death is expiate.

sp.speaker: RIVERS
sp.p:
Come, Grey, come, Vaughan, let us all embrace:
And take our leave, until we meet in heaven.

p.stage: Enter BUCKINGHAM, DERBY, HASTINGS, the BISHOP OF ELY, RATCLIFF, LOVEL, with others, and take their seats at a table

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
My lords, at once: the cause why we are met
Is, to determine of the coronation.
In God's name, speak: when is the royal day?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Are all things fitting for that royal time?

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p: It is, and wants but nomination.

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p: To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Who knows the lord protector's mind herein?
Who is most inward with the royal duke?

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p: Your grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Who, I, my lord I we know each other's faces,
But for our hearts, he knows no more of mine,
Than I of yours;
Nor I no more of his, than you of mine.
Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
I thank his grace, I know he loves me well;
But, for his purpose in the coronation.
I have not sounded him, nor he deliver'd
His gracious pleasure any way therein:
But you, my noble lords, may name the time;
And in the duke's behalf I'll give my voice,
Which, I presume, he'll take in gentle part.

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p: Now in good time, here comes the duke himself.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.
I have been long a sleeper; but, I hope,
My absence doth neglect no great designs,
Which by my presence might have been concluded.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Had not you come upon your cue, my lord
William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part,—
I mean, your voice,—for crowning of the king.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder;
His lordship knows me well, and loves me well.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: My lord of Ely!

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p: My lord?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
When I was last in Holborn,
I saw good strawberries in your garden there
I do beseech you send for some of them.

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p: Marry, and will, my lord, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.

Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business,
And finds the testy gentleman so hot,
As he will lose his head ere give consent
His master's son, as worshipful as he terms it,
Shall lose the royalty of England's throne.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Withdraw you hence, my lord, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p:
We have not yet set down this day of triumph.
To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;
For I myself am not so well provided
As else I would be, were the day prolong'd.

sp.speaker: BISHOP OF ELY
sp.p:
Where is my lord protector? I have sent for these
strawberries.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
DERBY
sp.p:
What of his heart perceive you in his face
By any likelihood he show'd to-day?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Marry, that with no man here he is offended;
For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p: I pray God he be not, I say.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I pray you all, tell me what they deserve
That do conspire my death with devilish plots
Of damned witchcraft, and that have prevail'd
Upon my body with their hellish charms?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
The tender love I bear your grace, my lord,
Makes me most forward in this noble presence
To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be
I say, my lord, they have deserved death.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Then be your eyes the witness of this ill:
See how I am bewitch'd; behold mine arm
Is, like a blasted sapling, wither'd up:
And this is Edward's wife, that monstrous witch,
Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,
That by their witchcraft thus have marked me.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p: If they have done this thing, my gracious lord—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
If I thou protector of this damned strumpet—
Tellest thou me of 'ifs'? Thou art a traitor:
Off with his head! Now, by Saint Paul I swear,
I will not dine until I see the same.
Lovel and Ratcliff, look that it be done:
The rest, that love me, rise and follow me.

p.stage: Exeunt all but HASTINGS, RATCLIFF, and LOVEL

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
Woe, woe for England! not a whit for me;
For I, too fond, might have prevented this.
Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm;
But I disdain'd it, and did scorn to fly:
Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,
And startled, when he look'd upon the Tower,
As loath to bear me to the slaughter-house.
O, now I want the priest that spake to me:
I now repent I told the pursuivant
As 'twere triumphing at mine enemies,
How they at Pomfret bloodily were butcher'd,
And I myself secure in grace and favour.
O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse
Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head!

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p:
Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:
Make a short shrift; he longs to see your head.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
O momentary grace of mortal men,
Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!
Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks,
Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,
Ready, with every nod, to tumble down
Into the fatal bowels of the deep.

sp.speaker: LOVEL
sp.p: Come, come, dispatch; 'tis bootless to exclaim.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS
sp.p:
O bloody Richard! miserable England!
I prophesy the fearful'st time to thee
That ever wretched age hath look'd upon.
Come, lead me to the block; bear him my head.
They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.

p.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, in rotten armour, marvellous ill-favoured

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Come, cousin, canst thou quake, and change thy colour,
Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,
And then begin again, and stop again,
As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian;
Speak and look back, and pry on every side,
Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,
Intending deep suspicion: ghastly looks
Are at my service, like enforced smiles;
And both are ready in their offices,
At any time, to grace my stratagems.
But what, is Catesby gone?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: He is; and, see, he brings the mayor along.

p.stage: Enter the Lord Mayor and CATESBY

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Lord mayor,—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Look to the drawbridge there!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Hark! a drum.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Catesby, o'erlook the walls.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Lord mayor, the reason we have sent—

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Look back, defend thee, here are enemies.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: God and our innocency defend and guard us!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Be patient, they are friends, Ratcliff and Lovel.

p.stage: Enter LOVEL and RATCLIFF, with HASTINGS' head

sp.speaker: LOVEL
sp.p:
Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,
The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
So dear I loved the man, that I must weep.
I took him for the plainest harmless creature
That breathed upon this earth a Christian;
Made him my book wherein my soul recorded
The history of all her secret thoughts:
So smooth he daub'd his vice with show of virtue,
That, his apparent open guilt omitted,
I mean, his conversation with Shore's wife,
He lived from all attainder of suspect.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Well, well, he was the covert'st shelter'd traitor
That ever lived.
Would you imagine, or almost believe,
Were't not that, by great preservation,
We live to tell it you, the subtle traitor
This day had plotted, in the council-house
To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: What, had he so?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
What, think You we are Turks or infidels?
Or that we would, against the form of law,
Proceed thus rashly to the villain's death,
But that the extreme peril of the case,
The peace of England and our persons' safety,
Enforced us to this execution?

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p:
Now, fair befall you! he deserved his death;
And you my good lords, both have well proceeded,
To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
I never look'd for better at his hands,
After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Yet had not we determined he should die,
Until your lordship came to see his death;
Which now the loving haste of these our friends,
Somewhat against our meaning, have prevented:
Because, my lord, we would have had you heard
The traitor speak, and timorously confess
The manner and the purpose of his treason;
That you might well have signified the same
Unto the citizens, who haply may
Misconstrue us in him and wail his death.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p:
But, my good lord, your grace's word shall serve,
As well as I had seen and heard him speak
And doubt you not, right noble princes both,
But I'll acquaint our duteous citizens
With all your just proceedings in this cause.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
And to that end we wish'd your lord-ship here,
To avoid the carping censures of the world.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
But since you come too late of our intents,
Yet witness what you hear we did intend:
And so, my good lord mayor, we bid farewell.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.
The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post:
There, at your meet'st advantage of the time,
Infer the bastardy of Edward's children:
Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen,
Only for saying he would make his son
Heir to the crown; meaning indeed his house,
Which, by the sign thereof was termed so.
Moreover, urge his hateful luxury
And bestial appetite in change of lust;
Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,
Even where his lustful eye or savage heart,
Without control, listed to make his prey.
Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:
Tell them, when that my mother went with child
Of that unsatiate Edward, noble York
My princely father then had wars in France
And, by just computation of the time,
Found that the issue was not his begot;
Which well appeared in his lineaments,
Being nothing like the noble duke my father:
But touch this sparingly, as 'twere far off,
Because you know, my lord, my mother lives.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator
As if the golden fee for which I plead
Were for myself: and so, my lord, adieu.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
I go: and towards three or four o'clock
Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw;

Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both
Meet me within this hour at Baynard's Castle.

Now will I in, to take some privy order,
To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight;
And to give notice, that no manner of person
At any time have recourse unto the princes.

p.stage: Enter a Scrivener, with a paper in his hand

sp.speaker: Scrivener
sp.p:
This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings;
Which in a set hand fairly is engross'd,
That it may be this day read over in Paul's.
And mark how well the sequel hangs together:
Eleven hours I spent to write it over,
For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me;
The precedent was full as long a-doing:
And yet within these five hours lived Lord Hastings,
Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty
Here's a good world the while! Why who's so gross,
That seeth not this palpable device?
Yet who's so blind, but says he sees it not?
Bad is the world; and all will come to nought,
When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.

p.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER and BUCKINGHAM, at several doors

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: How now, my lord, what say the citizens?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,
The citizens are mum and speak not a word.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy,
And his contract by deputy in France;
The insatiate greediness of his desires,
And his enforcement of the city wives;
His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,
As being got, your father then in France,
His resemblance, being not like the duke;
Withal I did infer your lineaments,
Being the right idea of your father,
Both in your form and nobleness of mind;
Laid open all your victories in Scotland,
Your dicipline in war, wisdom in peace,
Your bounty, virtue, fair humility:
Indeed, left nothing fitting for the purpose
Untouch'd, or slightly handled, in discourse
And when mine oratory grew to an end
I bid them that did love their country's good
Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Ah! and did they so?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
No, so God help me, they spake not a word;
But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,
Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.
Which when I saw, I reprehended them;
And ask'd the mayor what meant this wilful silence:
His answer was, the people were not wont
To be spoke to but by the recorder.
Then he was urged to tell my tale again,
'Thus saith the duke, thus hath the duke inferr'd;'
But nothing spake in warrant from himself.
When he had done, some followers of mine own,
At the lower end of the hall, hurl'd up their caps,
And some ten voices cried 'God save King Richard!'
And thus I took the vantage of those few,
'Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,' quoth I;
'This general applause and loving shout
Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard:'
And even here brake off, and came away.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: What tongueless blocks were they! would not they speak?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: No, by my troth, my lord.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
The mayor is here at hand: intend some fear;
Be not you spoke with, but by mighty suit:
And look you get a prayer-book in your hand,
And stand betwixt two churchmen, good my lord;
For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:
And be not easily won to our request:
Play the maid's part, still answer nay, and take it.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I go; and if you plead as well for them
As I can say nay to thee for myself,
No doubt well bring it to a happy issue.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.

p.stage: Enter the Lord Mayor and Citizens

sp.p:
Welcome my lord; I dance attendance here;
I think the duke will not be spoke withal.

Here comes his servant: how now, Catesby,
What says he?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Return, good Catesby, to thy lord again;
Tell him, myself, the mayor and citizens,
In deep designs and matters of great moment,
No less importing than our general good,
Are come to have some conference with his grace.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: I'll tell him what you say, my lord.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!
He is not lolling on a lewd day-bed,
But on his knees at meditation;
Not dallying with a brace of courtezans,
But meditating with two deep divines;
Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,
But praying, to enrich his watchful soul:
Happy were England, would this gracious prince
Take on himself the sovereignty thereof:
But, sure, I fear, we shall ne'er win him to it.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: Marry, God forbid his grace should say us nay!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: I fear he will.
How now, Catesby, what says your lord?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
My lord,
He wonders to what end you have assembled
Such troops of citizens to speak with him,
His grace not being warn'd thereof before:
My lord, he fears you mean no good to him.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Sorry I am my noble cousin should
Suspect me, that I mean no good to him:
By heaven, I come in perfect love to him;
And so once more return and tell his grace.

When holy and devout religious men
Are at their beads, 'tis hard to draw them thence,
So sweet is zealous contemplation.

p.stage: Enter GLOUCESTER aloft, between two Bishops. CATESBY returns

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: See, where he stands between two clergymen!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,
To stay him from the fall of vanity:
And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,
True ornaments to know a holy man.
Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,
Lend favourable ears to our request;
And pardon us the interruption
Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
My lord, there needs no such apology:
I rather do beseech you pardon me,
Who, earnest in the service of my God,
Neglect the visitation of my friends.
But, leaving this, what is your grace's pleasure?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above,
And all good men of this ungovern'd isle.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I do suspect I have done some offence
That seems disgracious in the city's eyes,
And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
You have, my lord: would it might please your grace,
At our entreaties, to amend that fault!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Then know, it is your fault that you resign
The supreme seat, the throne majestical,
The scepter'd office of your ancestors,
Your state of fortune and your due of birth,
The lineal glory of your royal house,
To the corruption of a blemished stock:
Whilst, in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,
Which here we waken to our country's good,
This noble isle doth want her proper limbs;
Her face defaced with scars of infamy,
Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,
And almost shoulder'd in the swallowing gulf
Of blind forgetfulness and dark oblivion.
Which to recure, we heartily solicit
Your gracious self to take on you the charge
And kingly government of this your land,
Not as protector, steward, substitute,
Or lowly factor for another's gain;
But as successively from blood to blood,
Your right of birth, your empery, your own.
For this, consorted with the citizens,
Your very worshipful and loving friends,
And by their vehement instigation,
In this just suit come I to move your grace.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
I know not whether to depart in silence,
Or bitterly to speak in your reproof.
Best fitteth my degree or your condition
If not to answer, you might haply think
Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,
Which fondly you would here impose on me;
If to reprove you for this suit of yours,
So season'd with your faithful love to me.
Then, on the other side, I cheque'd my friends.
Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,
And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,
Definitively thus I answer you.
Your love deserves my thanks; but my desert
Unmeritable shuns your high request.
First if all obstacles were cut away,
And that my path were even to the crown,
As my ripe revenue and due by birth
Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,
So mighty and so many my defects,
As I had rather hide me from my greatness,
Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,
Than in my greatness covet to be hid,
And in the vapour of my glory smother'd.
But, God be thank'd, there's no need of me,
And much I need to help you, if need were;
The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,
Which, mellow'd by the stealing hours of time,
Will well become the seat of majesty,
And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.
On him I lay what you would lay on me,
The right and fortune of his happy stars;
Which God defend that I should wring from him!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
My lord, this argues conscience in your grace;
But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,
All circumstances well considered.
You say that Edward is your brother's son:
So say we too, but not by Edward's wife;
For first he was contract to Lady Lucy—
Your mother lives a witness to that vow—
And afterward by substitute betroth'd
To Bona, sister to the King of France.
These both put by a poor petitioner,
A care-crazed mother of a many children,
A beauty-waning and distressed widow,
Even in the afternoon of her best days,
Made prize and purchase of his lustful eye,
Seduced the pitch and height of all his thoughts
To base declension and loathed bigamy
By her, in his unlawful bed, he got
This Edward, whom our manners term the prince.
More bitterly could I expostulate,
Save that, for reverence to some alive,
I give a sparing limit to my tongue.
Then, good my lord, take to your royal self
This proffer'd benefit of dignity;
If non to bless us and the land withal,
Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry
From the corruption of abusing times,
Unto a lineal true-derived course.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffer'd love.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: O, make them joyful, grant their lawful suit!

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
If you refuse it,—as, in love and zeal,
Loath to depose the child, Your brother's son;
As well we know your tenderness of heart
And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,
Which we have noted in you to your kin,
And egally indeed to all estates,—
Yet whether you accept our suit or no,
Your brother's son shall never reign our king;
But we will plant some other in the throne,
To the disgrace and downfall of your house:
And in this resolution here we leave you.—
Come, citizens: 'zounds! I'll entreat no more.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: Call them again, my lord, and accept their suit.

sp.speaker: ANOTHER
sp.p: Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Would you enforce me to a world of care?
Well, call them again. I am not made of stone,
But penetrable to your. kind entreats,
Albeit against my conscience and my soul.

Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men,
Since you will buckle fortune on my back,
To bear her burthen, whether I will or no,
I must have patience to endure the load:
But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach
Attend the sequel of your imposition,
Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me
From all the impure blots and stains thereof;
For God he knows, and you may partly see,
How far I am from the desire thereof.

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor
sp.p: God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: In saying so, you shall but say the truth.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Then I salute you with this kingly title:
Long live Richard, England's royal king!

sp.speaker: Lord Mayor, Citizens
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p: Even when you please, since you will have it so.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace:
And so most joyfully we take our leave.

sp.speaker: GLOUCESTER
sp.p:
Come, let us to our holy task again.
Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.

p.stage: Enter, on one side, QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS OF YORK, and DORSET; on the other, ANNE, Duchess of Gloucester, leading Lady Margaret Plantagenet, CLARENCE's young Daughter

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Who meets us here? my niece Plantagenet
Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?
Now, for my life, she's wandering to the Tower,
On pure heart's love to greet the tender princes.
Daughter, well met.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
God give your graces both
A happy and a joyful time of day!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: As much to you, good sister! Whither away?

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
No farther than the Tower; and, as I guess,
Upon the like devotion as yourselves,
To gratulate the gentle princes there.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Kind sister, thanks: we'll enter all together.

And, in good time, here the lieutenant comes.
Master lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,
How doth the prince, and my young son of York?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: The king! why, who's that?

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p: I cry you mercy: I mean the lord protector.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
The Lord protect him from that kingly title!
Hath he set bounds betwixt their love and me?
I am their mother; who should keep me from them?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I am their fathers mother; I will see them.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother:
Then bring me to their sights; I'll bear thy blame
And take thy office from thee, on my peril.

sp.speaker: BRAKENBURY
sp.p:
No, madam, no; I may not leave it so:
I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.

sp.speaker: LORD STANLEY
sp.p:
Let me but meet you, ladies, one hour hence,
And I'll salute your grace of York as mother,
And reverend looker on, of two fair queens.

Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,
There to be crowned Richard's royal queen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O, cut my lace in sunder, that my pent heart
May have some scope to beat, or else I swoon
With this dead-killing news!

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!

sp.speaker: DORSET
sp.p: Be of good cheer: mother, how fares your grace?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O Dorset, speak not to me, get thee hence!
Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;
Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
If thou wilt outstrip death, go cross the seas,
And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell
Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,
Lest thou increase the number of the dead;
And make me die the thrall of Margaret's curse,
Nor mother, wife, nor England's counted queen.

sp.speaker: LORD STANLEY
sp.p:
Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.
Take all the swift advantage of the hours;
You shall have letters from me to my son
To meet you on the way, and welcome you.
Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
O ill-dispersing wind of misery!
O my accursed womb, the bed of death!
A cockatrice hast thou hatch'd to the world,
Whose unavoided eye is murderous.

sp.speaker: LORD STANLEY
sp.p: Come, madam, come; I in all haste was sent.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
And I in all unwillingness will go.
I would to God that the inclusive verge
Of golden metal that must round my brow
Were red-hot steel, to sear me to the brain!
Anointed let me be with deadly venom,
And die, ere men can say, God save the queen!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory
To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p:
No! why? When he that is my husband now
Came to me, as I follow'd Henry's corse,
When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands
Which issued from my other angel husband
And that dead saint which then I weeping follow'd;
O, when, I say, I look'd on Richard's face,
This was my wish: 'Be thou,' quoth I, ' accursed,
For making me, so young, so old a widow!
And, when thou wed'st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;
And be thy wife—if any be so mad—
As miserable by the life of thee
As thou hast made me by my dear lord's death!
Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,
Even in so short a space, my woman's heart
Grossly grew captive to his honey words
And proved the subject of my own soul's curse,
Which ever since hath kept my eyes from rest;
For never yet one hour in his bed
Have I enjoy'd the golden dew of sleep,
But have been waked by his timorous dreams.
Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick;
And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Poor heart, adieu! I pity thy complaining.

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!

sp.speaker: LADY ANNE
sp.p: Adieu, poor soul, that takest thy leave of it!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee!
Go thou to Richard, and good angels guard thee!

Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee!
I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me!
Eighty odd years of sorrow have I seen,
And each hour's joy wrecked with a week of teen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.
Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes
Whom envy hath immured within your walls!
Rough cradle for such little pretty ones!
Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow
For tender princes, use my babies well!
So foolish sorrow bids your stones farewell.

p.stage: Sennet. Enter KING RICHARD III, in pomp, crowned; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a page, and others

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Stand all apart Cousin of Buckingham!

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: My gracious sovereign?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Give me thy hand.

Thus high, by thy advice
And thy assistance, is King Richard seated;
But shall we wear these honours for a day?
Or shall they last, and we rejoice in them?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Still live they and for ever may they last!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
O Buckingham, now do I play the touch,
To try if thou be current gold indeed
Young Edward lives: think now what I would say.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Say on, my loving lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Why, Buckingham, I say, I would be king,

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Why, so you are, my thrice renowned liege.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Ha! am I king? 'tis so: but Edward lives.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: True, noble prince.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
O bitter consequence,
That Edward still should live! 'True, noble prince!'
Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:
Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead;
And I would have it suddenly perform'd.
What sayest thou? speak suddenly; be brief.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Your grace may do your pleasure.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Tut, tut, thou art all ice, thy kindness freezeth:
Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord
Before I positively herein:
I will resolve your grace immediately.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: The king is angry: see, he bites the lip.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
I will converse with iron-witted fools
And unrespective boys: none are for me
That look into me with considerate eyes:
High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.
Boy!

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: My lord?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Know'st thou not any whom corrupting gold
Would tempt unto a close exploit of death?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
My lord, I know a discontented gentleman,
Whose humble means match not his haughty mind:
Gold were as good as twenty orators,
And will, no doubt, tempt him to any thing.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: I partly know the man: go, call him hither.

The deep-revolving witty Buckingham
No more shall be the neighbour to my counsel:
Hath he so long held out with me untired,
And stops he now for breath?
How now! what news with you?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
My lord, I hear the Marquis Dorset's fled
To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea
Where he abides.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Catesby!

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: My lord?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Rumour it abroad
That Anne, my wife, is sick and like to die:
I will take order for her keeping close.
Inquire me out some mean-born gentleman,
Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter:
The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.
Look, how thou dream'st! I say again, give out
That Anne my wife is sick and like to die:
About it; for it stands me much upon,
To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.

I must be married to my brother's daughter,
Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.
Murder her brothers, and then marry her!
Uncertain way of gain! But I am in
So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin:
Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
Is thy name Tyrrel?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p: James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Art thou, indeed?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p: Prove me, my gracious sovereign.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p:
Ay, my lord;
But I had rather kill two enemies.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Why, there thou hast it: two deep enemies,
Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers
Are they that I would have thee deal upon:
Tyrrel, I mean those bastards in the Tower.

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p:
Let me have open means to come to them,
And soon I'll rid you from the fear of them.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel
Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:

There is no more but so: say it is done,
And I will love thee, and prefer thee too.

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p: 'Tis done, my gracious lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Shall we hear from thee, Tyrrel, ere we sleep?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p: Ye shall, my Lord.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
My Lord, I have consider'd in my mind
The late demand that you did sound me in.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Well, let that pass. Dorset is fled to Richmond.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: I hear that news, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Stanley, he is your wife's son well, look to it.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
My lord, I claim your gift, my due by promise,
For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;
The earldom of Hereford and the moveables
The which you promised I should possess.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Stanley, look to your wife; if she convey
Letters to Richmond, you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: What says your highness to my just demand?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
As I remember, Henry the Sixth
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
A king, perhaps, perhaps,—

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
How chance the prophet could not at that time
Have told me, I being by, that I should kill him?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: My lord, your promise for the earldom,—

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Richmond! When last I was at Exeter,
The mayor in courtesy show'd me the castle,
And call'd it Rougemont: at which name I started,
Because a bard of Ireland told me once
I should not live long after I saw Richmond.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Ay, what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
I am thus bold to put your grace in mind
Of what you promised me.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Well, but what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Upon the stroke of ten.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Well, let it strike.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Why let it strike?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Because that, like a Jack, thou keep'st the stroke
Betwixt thy begging and my meditation.
I am not in the giving vein to-day.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Why, then resolve me whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Tut, tut,
Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Is it even so? rewards he my true service
With such deep contempt made I him king for this?
O, let me think on Hastings, and be gone
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p:
The tyrannous and bloody deed is done.
The most arch of piteous massacre
That ever yet this land was guilty of.
Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn
To do this ruthless piece of butchery,
Although they were flesh'd villains, bloody dogs,
Melting with tenderness and kind compassion
Wept like two children in their deaths' sad stories.
'Lo, thus' quoth Dighton, 'lay those tender babes:'
'Thus, thus,' quoth Forrest, 'girdling one another
Within their innocent alabaster arms:
Their lips were four red roses on a stalk,
Which in their summer beauty kiss'd each other.
A book of prayers on their pillow lay;
Which once,' quoth Forrest, 'almost changed my mind;
But O! the devil'—there the villain stopp'd
Whilst Dighton thus told on: 'We smothered
The most replenished sweet work of nature,
That from the prime creation e'er she framed.'
Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;
They could not speak; and so I left them both,
To bring this tidings to the bloody king.
And here he comes.
All hail, my sovereign liege!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Kind Tyrrel, am I happy in thy news?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p:
If to have done the thing you gave in charge
Beget your happiness, be happy then,
For it is done, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: But didst thou see them dead?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p: I did, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: And buried, gentle Tyrrel?

sp.speaker: TYRREL
sp.p:
The chaplain of the Tower hath buried them;
But how or in what place I do not know.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Come to me, Tyrrel, soon at after supper,
And thou shalt tell the process of their death.
Meantime, but think how I may do thee good,
And be inheritor of thy desire.
Farewell till soon.

The son of Clarence have I pent up close;
His daughter meanly have I match'd in marriage;
The sons of Edward sleep in Abraham's bosom,
And Anne my wife hath bid the world good night.
Now, for I know the Breton Richmond aims
At young Elizabeth, my brother's daughter,
And, by that knot, looks proudly o'er the crown,
To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Good news or bad, that thou comest in so bluntly?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Than Buckingham and his rash-levied army.
Come, I have heard that fearful commenting
Is leaden servitor to dull delay;
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary
Then fiery expedition be my wing,
Jove's Mercury, and herald for a king!
Come, muster men: my counsel is my shield;
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
So, now prosperity begins to mellow
And drop into the rotten mouth of death.
Here in these confines slily have I lurk'd,
To watch the waning of mine adversaries.
A dire induction am I witness to,
And will to France, hoping the consequence
Will prove as bitter, black, and tragical.
Withdraw thee, wretched Margaret: who comes here?

p.stage: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH and the DUCHESS OF YORK

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Ah, my young princes! ah, my tender babes!
My unblown flowers, new-appearing sweets!
If yet your gentle souls fly in the air
And be not fix'd in doom perpetual,
Hover about me with your airy wings
And hear your mother's lamentation!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Hover about her; say, that right for right
Hath dimm'd your infant morn to aged night.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
So many miseries have crazed my voice,
That my woe-wearied tongue is mute and dumb,
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Plantagenet doth quit Plantagenet.
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Wilt thou, O God, fly from such gentle lambs,
And throw them in the entrails of the wolf?
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Blind sight, dead life, poor mortal living ghost,
Woe's scene, world's shame, grave's due by life usurp'd,
Brief abstract and record of tedious days,
Rest thy unrest on England's lawful earth,
Unlawfully made drunk with innocents' blood!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O, that thou wouldst as well afford a grave
As thou canst yield a melancholy seat!
Then would I hide my bones, not rest them here.
O, who hath any cause to mourn but I?

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
If ancient sorrow be most reverend,
Give mine the benefit of seniory,
And let my woes frown on the upper hand.
If sorrow can admit society,

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
I had a Richard too, and thou didst kill him;
I had a Rutland too, thou holp'st to kill him.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
A hell-hound that doth hunt us all to death:
That dog, that had his teeth before his eyes,
To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,
That foul defacer of God's handiwork,
That excellent grand tyrant of the earth,
That reigns in galled eyes of weeping souls,
Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.
O upright, just, and true-disposing God,
How do I thank thee, that this carnal cur
Preys on the issue of his mother's body,
And makes her pew-fellow with others' moan!

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
O Harry's wife, triumph not in my woes!
God witness with me, I have wept for thine.

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p:
Bear with me; I am hungry for revenge,
And now I cloy me with beholding it.
Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:
Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
Young York he is but boot, because both they
Match not the high perfection of my loss:
Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
And the beholders of this tragic play,
The adulterate Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey,
Untimely smother'd in their dusky graves.
Richard yet lives, hell's black intelligencer,
Only reserved their factor, to buy souls
And send them thither: but at hand, at hand,
Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:
Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.
To have him suddenly convey'd away.
Cancel his bond of life, dear God, I prey,
That I may live to say, The dog is dead!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O, thou didst prophesy the time would come
That I should wish for thee to help me curse
That bottled spider, that foul bunch-back'd toad!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O thou well skill'd in curses, stay awhile,
And teach me how to curse mine enemies!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: My words are dull; O, quicken them with thine!

sp.speaker: QUEEN MARGARET
sp.p: Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Why should calamity be full of words?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Windy attorneys to their client woes,
Airy succeeders of intestate joys,
Poor breathing orators of miseries!
Let them have scope: though what they do impart
Help not all, yet do they ease the heart.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
If so, then be not tongue-tied: go with me.
And in the breath of bitter words let's smother
My damned son, which thy two sweet sons smother'd.
I hear his drum: be copious in exclaims.

p.stage: Enter KING RICHARD III, marching, with drums and trumpets

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Who intercepts my expedition?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
O, she that might have intercepted thee,
By strangling thee in her accursed womb
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Hidest thou that forehead with a golden crown,
Where should be graven, if that right were right,
The slaughter of the prince that owed that crown,
And the dire death of my two sons and brothers?
Tell me, thou villain slave, where are my children?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?
And little Ned Plantagenet, his son?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Where is kind Hastings, Rivers, Vaughan, Grey?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
A flourish, trumpets! strike alarum, drums!
Let not the heavens hear these tell-tale women
Rail on the Lord's enointed: strike, I say!

Either be patient, and entreat me fair,
Or with the clamorous report of war
Thus will I drown your exclamations.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Art thou my son?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Ay, I thank God, my father, and yourself.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: Then patiently hear my impatience.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Madam, I have a touch of your condition,
Which cannot brook the accent of reproof.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: O, let me speak!

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Do then: but I'll not hear.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I will be mild and gentle in my speech.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: And brief, good mother; for I am in haste.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Art thou so hasty? I have stay'd for thee,
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: And came I not at last to comfort you?

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
No, by the holy rood, thou know'st it well,
Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.
A grievous burthen was thy birth to me;
Tetchy and wayward was thy infancy;
Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,
Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,
treacherous,
More mild, but yet more harmful, kind in hatred:
What comfortable hour canst thou name,
That ever graced me in thy company?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd
your grace
To breakfast once forth of my company.
If I be so disgracious in your sight,
Let me march on, and not offend your grace.
Strike the drum.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p: I prithee, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: You speak too bitterly.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Hear me a word;
For I shall never speak to thee again.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: DUCHESS OF YORK
sp.p:
Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Or I with grief and extreme age shall perish
And never look upon thy face again.
Therefore take with thee my most heavy curse;
Which, in the day of battle, tire thee more
Than all the complete armour that thou wear'st!
My prayers on the adverse party fight;
And there the little souls of Edward's children
Whisper the spirits of thine enemies
And promise them success and victory.
Bloody thou art, bloody will be thy end;
Shame serves thy life and doth thy death attend.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Abides in me; I say amen to all.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Stay, madam; I must speak a word with you.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
I have no more sons of the royal blood
For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard,
They shall be praying nuns, not weeping queens;
And therefore level not to hit their lives.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
You have a daughter call'd Elizabeth,
Virtuous and fair, royal and gracious.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Wrong not her birth, she is of royal blood.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: To save her life, I'll say she is not so.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Her life is only safest in her birth.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: And only in that safety died her brothers.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Lo, at their births good stars were opposite.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: No, to their lives bad friends were contrary.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: All unavoided is the doom of destiny.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
True, when avoided grace makes destiny:
My babes were destined to a fairer death,
If grace had bless'd thee with a fairer life.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: You speak as if that I had slain my cousins.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd
Of comfort, kingdom, kindred, freedom, life.
Whose hand soever lanced their tender hearts,
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:
No doubt the murderous knife was dull and blunt
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,
To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
But that still use of grief makes wild grief tame,
My tongue should to thy ears not name my boys
Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
And I, in such a desperate bay of death,
Like a poor bark, of sails and tackling reft,
Rush all to pieces on thy rocky bosom.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Madam, so thrive I in my enterprise
And dangerous success of bloody wars,
As I intend more good to you and yours,
Than ever you or yours were by me wrong'd!

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
What good is cover'd with the face of heaven,
To be discover'd, that can do me good?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: The advancement of your children, gentle lady.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Up to some scaffold, there to lose their heads?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
No, to the dignity and height of honour
The high imperial type of this earth's glory.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,
Will I withal endow a child of thine;
So in the Lethe of thy angry soul
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Which thou supposest I have done to thee.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Be brief, lest that be process of thy kindness
Last longer telling than thy kindness' date.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Then know, that from my soul I love thy daughter.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: My daughter's mother thinks it with her soul.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: What do you think?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Be not so hasty to confound my meaning:
I mean, that with my soul I love thy daughter,
And mean to make her queen of England.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Say then, who dost thou mean shall be her king?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Even he that makes her queen who should be else?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: What, thou?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: I, even I: what think you of it, madam?

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: How canst thou woo her?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
That would I learn of you,
As one that are best acquainted with her humour.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: And wilt thou learn of me?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Madam, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Send to her, by the man that slew her brothers,
A pair of bleeding-hearts; thereon engrave
Edward and York; then haply she will weep:
Therefore present to her—as sometime Margaret
Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,—
A handkerchief; which, say to her, did drain
The purple sap from her sweet brother's body
And bid her dry her weeping eyes therewith.
If this inducement force her not to love,
Send her a story of thy noble acts;
Tell her thou madest away her uncle Clarence,
Her uncle Rivers; yea, and, for her sake,
Madest quick conveyance with her good aunt Anne.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Come, come, you mock me; this is not the way
To win our daughter.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
There is no other way
Unless thou couldst put on some other shape,
And not be Richard that hath done all this.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Say that I did all this for love of her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
Nay, then indeed she cannot choose but hate thee,
Having bought love with such a bloody spoil.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Look, what is done cannot be now amended:
Men shall deal unadvisedly sometimes,
Which after hours give leisure to repent.
If I did take the kingdom from your sons,
To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter.
If I have kill'd the issue of your womb,
To quicken your increase, I will beget
Mine issue of your blood upon your daughter
A grandam's name is little less in love
Than is the doting title of a mother;
They are as children but one step below,
Even of your mettle, of your very blood;
Of an one pain, save for a night of groans
Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.
Your children were vexation to your youth,
But mine shall be a comfort to your age.
The loss you have is but a son being king,
And by that loss your daughter is made queen.
I cannot make you what amends I would,
Therefore accept such kindness as I can.
Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul
Leads discontented steps in foreign soil,
This fair alliance quickly shall call home
To high promotions and great dignity:
The king, that calls your beauteous daughter wife.
Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;
Again shall you be mother to a king,
And all the ruins of distressful times
Repair'd with double riches of content.
What! we have many goodly days to see:
The liquid drops of tears that you have shed
Shall come again, transform'd to orient pearl,
Advantaging their loan with interest
Of ten times double gain of happiness.
Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go
Make bold her bashful years with your experience;
Prepare her ears to hear a wooer's tale
Put in her tender heart the aspiring flame
Of golden sovereignty; acquaint the princess
With the sweet silent hours of marriage joys
And when this arm of mine hath chastised
The petty rebel, dull-brain'd Buckingham,
Bound with triumphant garlands will I come
And lead thy daughter to a conqueror's bed;
To whom I will retail my conquest won,
And she shall be sole victress, Caesar's Caesar.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
What were I best to say? her father's brother
Would be her lord? or shall I say, her uncle?
Or, he that slew her brothers and her uncles?
Under what title shall I woo for thee,
That God, the law, my honour and her love,
Can make seem pleasing to her tender years?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Infer fair England's peace by this alliance.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Which she shall purchase with still lasting war.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Say that the king, which may command, entreats.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: That at her hands which the king's King forbids.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Say, she shall be a high and mighty queen.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: To wail the tide, as her mother doth.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Say, I will love her everlastingly.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: But how long shall that title 'ever' last?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Sweetly in force unto her fair life's end.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: But how long fairly shall her sweet lie last?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: So long as heaven and nature lengthens it.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: So long as hell and Richard likes of it.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Say, I, her sovereign, am her subject love.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: But she, your subject, loathes such sovereignty.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Be eloquent in my behalf to her.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: An honest tale speeds best being plainly told.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Then in plain terms tell her my loving tale.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Plain and not honest is too harsh a style.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Your reasons are too shallow and too quick.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
O no, my reasons are too deep and dead;
Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Harp not on that string, madam; that is past.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Harp on it still shall I till heart-strings break.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Now, by my George, my garter, and my crown,—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Profaned, dishonour'd, and the third usurp'd.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: I swear—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Now, by the world—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: 'Tis full of thy foul wrongs.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: My father's death—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Thy life hath that dishonour'd.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Then, by myself—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Thyself thyself misusest.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Why then, by God—

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
God's wrong is most of all.
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,
The unity the king thy brother made
Had not been broken, nor my brother slain:
If thou hadst fear'd to break an oath by Him,
The imperial metal, circling now thy brow,
Had graced the tender temples of my child,
And both the princes had been breathing here,
Which now, two tender playfellows to dust,
Thy broken faith hath made a prey for worms.
What canst thou swear by now?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: The time to come.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
That thou hast wronged in the time o'erpast;
For I myself have many tears to wash
Hereafter time, for time past wrong'd by thee.
The children live, whose parents thou hast
slaughter'd,
Ungovern'd youth, to wail it in their age;
The parents live, whose children thou hast butcher'd,
Old wither'd plants, to wail it with their age.
Swear not by time to come; for that thou hast
Misused ere used, by time misused o'erpast.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
As I intend to prosper and repent,
So thrive I in my dangerous attempt
Of hostile arms! myself myself confound!
Heaven and fortune bar me happy hours!
Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!
Be opposite all planets of good luck
To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love,
Immaculate devotion, holy thoughts,
I tender not thy beauteous princely daughter!
In her consists my happiness and thine;
Without her, follows to this land and me,
To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul,
Death, desolation, ruin and decay:
It cannot be avoided but by this;
It will not be avoided but by this.
Therefore, good mother,—I must can you so—
Be the attorney of my love to her:
Plead what I will be, not what I have been;
Not my deserts, but what I will deserve:
Urge the necessity and state of times,
And be not peevish-fond in great designs.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Shall I be tempted of the devil thus?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Ay, if the devil tempt thee to do good.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Shall I forget myself to be myself?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Ay, if yourself's remembrance wrong yourself.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: But thou didst kill my children.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
But in your daughter's womb I bury them:
Where in that nest of spicery they shall breed
Selves of themselves, to your recomforture.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p: Shall I go win my daughter to thy will?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: And be a happy mother by the deed.

sp.speaker: QUEEN ELIZABETH
sp.p:
I go. Write to me very shortly.
And you shall understand from me her mind.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Bear her my true love's kiss; and so, farewell.
Relenting fool, and shallow, changing woman!
How now! what news?

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p:
My gracious sovereign, on the western coast
Rideth a puissant navy; to the shore
Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,
Unarm'd, and unresolved to beat them back:
'Tis thought that Richmond is their admiral;
And there they hull, expecting but the aid
Of Buckingham to welcome them ashore.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Some light-foot friend post to the Duke of Norfolk:
Ratcliff, thyself, or Catesby; where is he?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Fly to the duke:

Post thou to Salisbury
When thou comest thither—

Dull, unmindful villain,
Why stand'st thou still, and go'st not to the duke?

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p:
First, mighty sovereign, let me know your mind,
What from your grace I shall deliver to him.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
O, true, good Catesby: bid him levy straight
The greatest strength and power he can make,
And meet me presently at Salisbury.

sp.speaker: CATESBY
sp.p: I go.

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p:
What is't your highness' pleasure I shall do at
Salisbury?

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Why, what wouldst thou do there before I go?

sp.speaker: RATCLIFF
sp.p: Your highness told me I should post before.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: My mind is changed, sir, my mind is changed.
How now, what news with you?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
None good, my lord, to please you with the hearing;
Nor none so bad, but it may well be told.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Hoyday, a riddle! neither good nor bad!
Why dost thou run so many mile about,
When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way?
Once more, what news?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: Richmond is on the seas.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
There let him sink, and be the seas on him!
White-liver'd runagate, what doth he there?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: I know not, mighty sovereign, but by guess.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Well, sir, as you guess, as you guess?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
Stirr'd up by Dorset, Buckingham, and Ely,
He makes for England, there to claim the crown.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Is the chair empty? is the sword unsway'd?
Is the king dead? the empire unpossess'd?
What heir of York is there alive but we?
And who is England's king but great York's heir?
Then, tell me, what doth he upon the sea?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: Unless for that, my liege, I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Unless for that he comes to be your liege,
You cannot guess wherefore the Welshman comes.
Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: No, mighty liege; therefore mistrust me not.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Where is thy power, then, to beat him back?
Where are thy tenants and thy followers?
Are they not now upon the western shore.
Safe-conducting the rebels from their ships!

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: No, my good lord, my friends are in the north.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Cold friends to Richard: what do they in the north,
When they should serve their sovereign in the west?

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
They have not been commanded, mighty sovereign:
Please it your majesty to give me leave,
I'll muster up my friends, and meet your grace
Where and what time your majesty shall please.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Ay, ay. thou wouldst be gone to join with Richmond:
I will not trust you, sir.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p:
Most mighty sovereign,
You have no cause to hold my friendship doubtful:
I never was nor never will be false.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Well,
Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind
Your son, George Stanley: look your faith be firm.
Or else his head's assurance is but frail.

sp.speaker: STANLEY
sp.p: So deal with him as I prove true to you.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.p:
My gracious sovereign, now in Devonshire,
As I by friends am well advertised,
Sir Edward Courtney, and the haughty prelate
Bishop of Exeter, his brother there,
With many more confederates, are in arms.

sp.speaker: Second Messenger
Third Messenger
sp.p: My lord, the army of the Duke of Buckingham—

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p: Out on you, owls! nothing but songs of death?
Take that, until thou bring me better news.

sp.speaker: Third Messenger
sp.p:
The news I have to tell your majesty
Is, that by sudden floods and fall of waters,
Buckingham's army is dispersed and scatter'd;
And he himself wander'd away alone,
No man knows whither.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
I cry thee mercy:
There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.
Hath any well-advised friend proclaim'd
Reward to him that brings the traitor in?

sp.speaker: Third Messenger
sp.p: Such proclamation hath been made, my liege.

sp.speaker: Fourth Messenger
sp.p:
Sir Thomas Lovel and Lord Marquis Dorset,
'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms.
Yet this good comfort bring I to your grace,
The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest:
Richmond, in Yorkshire, sent out a boat
Unto the shore, to ask those on the banks
If they were his assistants, yea or no;
Who answer'd him, they came from Buckingham.
Upon his party: he, mistrusting them,
Hoisted sail and made away for Brittany.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
CATESBY
sp.p:
My liege, the Duke of Buckingham is taken;
That is the best news: that the Earl of Richmond
Is with a mighty power landed at Milford,
Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.

sp.speaker: KING RICHARD III
sp.p:
Away towards Salisbury! while we reason here,
A royal battle might be won and lost
Some one take order Buckingham be brought
To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.

p.stage: Enter DERBY and SIR CHRISTOPHER URSWICK

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p:
Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me:
That in the sty of this most bloody boar
My son George Stanley is frank'd up in hold:
If I revolt, off goes young George's head;
The fear of that withholds my present aid.
But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
sp.p: At Pembroke, or at Harford-west, in Wales.

sp.speaker: DERBY
sp.p: What men of name resort to him?

sp.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
DERBY
sp.p:
Return unto thy lord; commend me to him:
Tell him the queen hath heartily consented
He shall espouse Elizabeth her daughter.
These letters will resolve him of my mind. Farewell.

p.stage: Enter the Sheriff, and BUCKINGHAM, with halberds, led to execution

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p: Will not King Richard let me speak with him?

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: No, my good lord; therefore be patient.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Hastings, and Edward's children, Rivers, Grey,
Holy King Henry, and thy fair son Edward,
Vaughan, and all that have miscarried
By underhand corrupted foul injustice,
If that your moody discontented souls
Do through the clouds behold this present hour,
Even for revenge mock my destruction!
This is All-Souls' day, fellows, is it not?

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: It is, my lord.

sp.speaker: BUCKINGHAM
sp.p:
Why, then All-Souls' day is my body's doomsday.
This is the day that, in King Edward's time,
I wish't might fall on me, when I was found
False to his children or his wife's allies
This is the day wherein I wish'd to fall
By the false faith of him I trusted most;
This, this All-Souls' day to my fearful soul
Is the determined respite of my wrongs:
That high All-Seer that I dallied with
Hath turn'd my feigned prayer on my head
And given in earnest what I begg'd in jest.
Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men
To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms:
Now Margaret's curse is fallen upon my head;
'When he,' quoth she, 'shall split thy heart with sorrow,
Remember Margaret was a prophetess.'
Come, sirs, convey me to the block of shame;
Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.

p.stage: Enter RICHMOND, OXFORD, BLUNT, HERBERT, and others, with drum and colours

sp.speaker: RICHMOND
sp.p:
Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends,
Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny,
Thus far into the bowels of the land
Have we march'd on without impediment;
And here receive we from our father Stanley
Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.
The wretched, bloody, and usurping boar,
That spoil'd your summer fields and fruitful vines,
Swills your warm blood like wash, and makes his trough
In your embowell'd bosoms, this foul swine
Lies now even in the centre of this isle,
Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn
From Tamworth thither is but one day's march.
In God's name, cheerly on, courageous friends,
To reap the harvest of perpetual peace
By this one bloody trial of sharp war.

sp.speaker: OXFORD
sp.p:
Every man's conscience is a thousand swords,
To fight against that bloody homicide.

sp.speaker: HERBERT
sp.p: I doubt not but his friends will fly to us.

sp.speaker: BLUNT
sp.p:
